Create an 'Input' component that is able to take in user input. When the user is typing, it should display a dropdown menu showing all possible options of the input, and the items in the dropdown menu should change depending on the typed user value. If the value doesn't exist, the dropdown menu should disappear. Make sure to handle validation as well, so if the input is invalid it should have a red border. Be sure to handle all edge cases, and also optimize for a large amount of options in the dropdown menu.

The tech stack used here is React and TypeScript.

question: How is it possible to add `\printbibliography` to the table of contents (`\tableofcontents`) when using `\usepackage[backend=bibtex,urldate=iso]{biblatex}`?
base_answer:
When using `biblatex` with `\printbibliography`, the bibliography is not automatically added to the table of contents. To include the bibliography in the table of contents, you typically need to explicitly add it via an option or a command.

Since you are using:
```latex
\usepackage[backend=bibtex,urldate=iso]{biblatex}
```
and want to add the bibliography to the table of contents, here is the standard way to do it:

### Method 1: Use the `heading` option with `\printbibliography`

The `\printbibliography` command accepts a `heading` option that controls the bibliography heading style. The default is usually `heading=bibintoc` or `heading=bibnumbered` if you want it numbered and included in the ToC.

Try this:

```latex
\printbibliography[heading=bibintoc]
```

- `bibintoc` â€” bibliography heading included in the ToC but unnumbered.
- `bibnumbered` â€” bibliography heading included in the ToC and numbered.

Example:

```latex
\documentclass{article}
\usepackage[backend=bibtex,urldate=iso]{biblatex}
\addbibresource{myrefs.bib}

\begin{document}

\tableofcontents

\section{Introduction}
Some citation \cite{somekey}.

% Print bibliography with heading included in ToC
\printbibliography[heading=bibintoc]

\end{document}
```

### Method 2: Manually add ToC entry

If for some reason the above does not work, you can manually add an entry to the table of contents before printing the bibliography:

```latex
\addcontentsline{toc}{section}{Bibliography}
\printbibliography
```

This adds a `section` entry named

to the table of contents.

---

### Summary

- The easiest and cleanest way is to use

```latex
\printbibliography[heading=bibintoc]
```

- Alternatively, manually add to ToC with `\addcontentsline`.

---

### References

- `biblatex` manual, section about bibliography headings:  
  https://ctan.org/pkg/biblatex?lang=en  
  (Look for

and `\printbibliography` options)

---

If you want the bibliography heading to be numbered and appear in the ToC:

```latex
\printbibliography[heading=bibnumbered]
```

Or if you want no heading at all:

```latex
\printbibliography[heading=none]
```

But then you need to add ToC entry manually if desired.

---

**Note:** `biblatex`'s default heading styles depend on document class and options, so specifying `heading=bibintoc` or `heading=bibnumbered` is the recommended way.

You are a very smart puzzle and math problem solver. You will use logic and reasoning to solve hard problems in the simplest way. You always follow all the rules precisely and fully. It is critical that you calculate and travel the shortest distance possible for every task, otherwise you will overheat and break down.

There is a pegboard containing 6 pegs arranged in 2 rows of 3. The pegs are numbered 1 to 3 in the top row (left to right) and pegs 4 to 6 in the bottom row (left to right). 

 
Scenario 1: Pegs 1,2, and 3 have no blocks. On Peg 4 there is an orange block, on peg 5 there are two blocks (pink on top of yellow), and on peg 6 there are three blocks (red, blue, green from top to bottom).

 
Scenario 3: Pegs 4 and 6 are empty. Peg 1 has only a red block, Peg 2 has only a blue block, and Peg 3 has only a yellow block. Peg 5 has 3 blocks (green at the top, orange in the middle, pink at the bottom).

 
Scenario 4: The same pegboard but the blocks are arranged as follows. Pegs 1,2, and 3 are empty. On peg 4 there are three blocks (red, blue, green from top to bottom), on peg 5 there are two blocks (yellow on top of pink), and on peg 6 there is an orange block.

Pegboard orientation 1: Peg 1 is at (1,2). Peg 2 is at (2,2). Peg 3 is at (3,2). Peg 4 is at (1,1). Peg 5 is at (2,1). Peg 6 is at (3,1). 
Pegboard orientation 2: Peg 1 is at (1,3). Peg 2 is at (2,2.5). Peg 3 is at (3,3). Peg 4 is at (1,1). Peg 5 is at (1.5,2.5). Peg 6 is at (2,1).

Task A: In Scenario 1, pegboard orientation 1, move the pink block to peg 4. 
Solution: Letâ€™s think step by step. First, I will calculate the distance between every set of pegs based on the peg coordinates. Second, I will check if there are any blocks on top of the block I want to move. The pink block is at the top of peg 5, so it can be moved in one step. Summarized Steps: Move the pink block from peg 5 to peg 4. 

Task B: In Scenario 1, pegboard orientation 1, move the green block to peg 1. 
Solution: Letâ€™s think step by step. First, I will calculate the distance between every set of pegs based on the peg coordinates. Second, I will check if there are any blocks on top of the block I want to move. There are two blocks on top of the green block on peg 6, so they must be moved to an arbitrary peg that is the shortest distance away and not full. Third, I will determine the optimal temporary pegs using the distance matrix I previously calculated. Assuming my calculation yields peg 3 and peg 5 are the minimum distance away from peg 6, I will check if either of them is at capacity. Peg 3 is not at capacity, so I will move the red block to peg 3. Next, I will check again which block is at the top of peg 6 because I need to reach the pink block on peg 6. The blue block is at the top now, so I will determine the closest peg that can hold the blue block. My first option is to reuse the peg that is the absolute shortest distance away, but I need to check if it has reached capacity to determine if I can use it again as a temporary hold. It only has one block on it, so it is not full yet, therefore I can use peg 3 again as a temporary hold for the blue block. Summarized Steps: Move the red block from peg 6 to peg 3, move the blue block from peg 6 to peg 3, and finally move the green block from peg 6 to peg 1.

Task C: In Scenario 1, pegboard orientation 1, swap the positions of the yellow and green blocks, but ensure that all the other blocks in the same position at the end. Initially, the yellow block is at the bottom of peg 5, and the green block is at the bottom of peg 6. I need to clear peg 6 using the closest peg so that I can place the yellow block at the bottom of peg 6. First I will calculate the distance between every set of pegs based on the peg coordinates so that I can choose the nearest peg for temporary storage. There is a red block on top of a blue block on top of the green block on peg 6. Peg 3 is the shortest distance away from peg 6 I the given configuration, and peg 3 has space for 3 blocks, so I will place the red block on it. Peg 3 still has space for 2 more blocks after I placed the red block, so I will place the blue block on it. Peg 3 still has space for 1 more block after I placed the blue block, so I will place the green block on it. Now that peg 6 is empty, the yellow block can be placed on the peg so that itâ€™s at the bottom of the stack. Before I can move the yellow block, I need to check if there is any block on top of it. There is a pink block on top of the yellow block on peg 5, so I must first move the pink block to a temporary peg that is the shortest distance away and is not full. Based on the distances I calculated earlier, both pegs 2, 4, and 6 are the closest to peg 5. Either peg 2 or peg 4 can be used because they both have less than 3 blocks and will not interfere with my next step. I will move the pink block to peg 2, then I will move the yellow block to peg 6. Since peg 5 is now empty, I can place the green block on it, and it will be at the bottom of the stack. Now that I have swapped the yellow and green block positions, I need to return all the other blocks to their initial positions. I will place the pink block on peg 5 so that is in the second position up. I will place the blue block on peg 6 so that is in the second position up. Lastly, I will place red block on peg 6 so that it is at the top. 
Summarized Steps: Move the red block to peg 3. Move the blue block to peg 3. Move the green block to peg 3. Move the pink block to peg 2. Move the yellow block to peg 6. Move the green block to peg 5. Move the pink block to peg 5. 6. Move blue block to peg 7. Move the red block to peg 6.

Rules:
-	Rule 1: Use the shortest path possible for every task.
-	Rule 2: Each peg is allowed to hold up to 3 blocks.

```python
def coeff(r, n):
    # Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼ĞµÑ€Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ€ĞµĞ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ñ, Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ Ğ²Ğ°ÑˆÑƒ Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¸ĞºÑƒ
    return r / (12 * n)

@njit
def calculate_balance_debt_numba(ear, r, Term, balance_prev, first_month):
    balance_debt = np.zeros(Term, dtype=np.float64)

    if first_month == 0:
        balance_debt[0] = balance_prev * (1 - ear[0])
    else:
        balance_debt[first_month] = balance_prev * (1 + r[0]/12 - coeff(r[0], Term + 1 - first_month)) - ear[0] * balance_prev

    length = min(len(ear) - 1, len(r), Term - first_month - 2)
    for i in range(length):
        idx_prev = i + first_month
        idx_curr = idx_prev + 1
        balance_debt[idx_curr] = balance_debt[idx_prev] * (1 + r[i]/12 - coeff(r[i], Term - i - first_month)) - ear[i+1] * balance_debt[idx_prev]

    return balance_debt
```

### Ğ˜ÑÑ…Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ ĞºĞ¾Ğ´ Ñ ÑƒĞ»ÑƒÑ‡ÑˆĞµĞ½Ğ¸ÑĞ¼Ğ¸:

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from numba import njit

# ĞŸÑ€Ğ¸Ğ¼ĞµÑ€ Ñ€ĞµĞ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ğ¸ coeff (Ğ·Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸ÑĞ¸Ñ‚ Ğ¾Ñ‚ Ğ²Ğ°ÑˆĞµĞ¹ Ğ·Ğ°Ğ´Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸)
def coeff(r, n):
    # Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼ĞµÑ€Ğ½Ğ°Ñ Ñ€ĞµĞ°Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ñ†Ğ¸Ñ, Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑĞ¹Ñ‚Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ´ Ğ²Ğ°ÑˆÑƒ Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ¸ĞºÑƒ
    return r / (12 * n)

@njit
def calculate_balance_debt_numba(ear, r, Term, balance_prev, first_month):
    balance_debt = np.zeros(Term, dtype=np.float64)

    if first_month == 0:
        balance_debt[0] = balance_prev * (1 - ear[0])
    else:
        balance_debt[first_month] = balance_prev * (1 + r[0]/12 - coeff(r[0], Term + 1 - first_month)) - ear[0] * balance_prev

    length = min(len(ear) - 1, len(r), Term - first_month - 2)
    for i in range(length):
        idx_prev = i + first_month
        idx_curr = idx_prev + 1
        balance_debt[idx_curr] = balance_debt[idx_prev] * (1 + r[i]/12 - coeff(r[i], Term - i - first_month)) - ear[i+1] * balance_debt[idx_prev]

    return balance_debt

# ĞŸĞ¾Ğ´Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ²ĞºĞ° Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ñ…

# ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ²Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‰Ğ°ĞµĞ¼ Ğ² DataFrame Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ¸ ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ€ÑŒ, ĞµÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ğ½ÑƒĞ¶Ğ½Ğ¾
balances_dict = dict(results)
```

- Ğ—Ğ°Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ÑĞµĞ¼ `.apply()` Ğ½Ğ° Ñ†Ğ¸ĞºĞ» Ñ Ğ³Ñ€ÑƒĞ¿Ğ¿Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²ĞºĞ¾Ğ¹, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾, ĞºĞ°Ğº Ğ±Ñ‹Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾ĞºĞ°Ğ·Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾, Ğ±Ñ‹ÑÑ‚Ñ€ĞµĞµ Ğ² Pandas.  Ğ—Ğ°Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ° `.apply()` Ğ½Ğ° ÑĞ²Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ñ†Ğ¸ĞºĞ» Ğ¾Ğ±ĞµÑĞ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½ÑƒÑ ÑÑ„Ñ„ĞµĞºÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ.
- ĞŸÑ€ĞµĞ´Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ `coeff` â€” Ğ½ĞµĞ±Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞ°Ñ Ñ„ÑƒĞ½ĞºÑ†Ğ¸Ñ, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€ÑƒÑ Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¾ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğµ ÑƒÑĞºĞ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ, Ğ»Ğ¸Ğ±Ğ¾ Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ±ĞµĞ· Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ¼ĞµĞ½ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹.  ĞšĞ¾ÑÑ„Ñ„Ğ¸Ñ†Ğ¸ĞµĞ½Ñ‚ `coeff`  Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ½Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ ÑƒÑĞºĞ¾Ñ€ÑĞµÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ¸ÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ·Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ĞµĞ¼ `@njit`  Ğ´Ğ»Ñ JIT-ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ¿Ğ¸Ğ»ÑÑ†Ğ¸Ğ¸.
- Ğ ĞµĞ·ÑƒĞ»ÑŒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ‚Ñ‹ ÑĞ¾Ğ±Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ² ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ€ÑŒ, Ğ° Ğ¿Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ¼ Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ¿ÑÑ‚ÑÑ Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ² DataFrame, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ¾Ğ±ĞµÑĞ¿ĞµÑ‡Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ Ğ³Ğ¸Ğ±ĞºĞ¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ»ÑŒĞ½ĞµĞ¹ÑˆĞµĞ¼ Ğ¸ÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒĞ·Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸Ğ¸.
- ĞÑ‚ÑĞ¾Ñ€Ñ‚Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ»ÑÑÑ‚ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ²Ñ‹ÑĞ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ÑŒĞ½Ğ¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞºĞ¸.  Ğ­Ñ‚Ğ¾ ÑƒĞ»ÑƒÑ‡ÑˆĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ‚ĞºĞ¸ Ğ´Ğ°Ğ½Ğ½Ñ‹Ñ….
